title: loan officer assitant

title: Product Manager
pros:
- Led end-to-end product development of an AI-driven embedded finance platform, enabling partner applications to deliver real-time credit decisions via APIs — reducing loan approval time from days to under 5 seconds.
- Defined product vision, strategy, and roadmap aligned with business objectives; collaborated with engineering, data science, and compliance teams to ensure innovation within FCRA, ECOA, and GDPR frameworks.
- Partnered with data scientists to design and deploy an explainable ML-based credit-scoring model, achieving 94% predictive accuracy and transparent outputs using SHAP-based interpretability.
- Managed a backlog of 40+ features, prioritized initiatives using the RICE framework, and delivered the MVP 20% ahead of schedule while maintaining enterprise-grade reliability and uptime.
- Launched a self-service partner dashboard enabling instant API integration, credit analytics, and performance monitoring — improving partner onboarding efficiency by 30%.
- Established measurable success metrics and continuous feedback loops, tracking KPIs such as approval-rate lift (+15%), model drift, and partner retention to drive iterative product optimization.
cons:
- Led end-to-end product development of an AI-driven embedded finance platform, enabling partner applications to deliver real-time credit decisions via APIs — reducing loan approval time from days to under 5 seconds.
- Defined product vision, strategy, and roadmap aligned with business objectives; collaborated with engineering, data science, and compliance teams to ensure innovation within FCRA, ECOA, and GDPR frameworks.
- Partnered with data scientists to design and deploy an explainable ML-based credit-scoring model, achieving 94% predictive accuracy and transparent outputs using SHAP-based interpretability.
- Managed a backlog of 40+ features, prioritized initiatives using the RICE framework, and delivered the MVP 20% ahead of schedule while maintaining enterprise-grade reliability and uptime.
- Launched a self-service partner dashboard enabling instant API integration, credit analytics, and performance monitoring — improving partner onboarding efficiency by 30%.

title: Great Experience But Frequent Layoffs
pros: JPM is a great place to work, with many opportunities and different lines of business to explore for career growth. You’re surrounded by many talented people.
cons: Recently, JPM has had layoffs and outsourced some roles to India and other parts of Asia. Additionally, advancements in AI technology are impacting certain positions.

title: Pros and cons
pros:
Great benefit payments
Great vacation packages (4 weeks)
Great team that priorities team building
Good work balance
cons:
5 days in office 
Expensive cafeteria food

title: Planning is more of a marketing initiative than a strategic initiative
pros: Guaranteed pay for a period of time and good benefits
cons: The firm is stuck to the old ways. They say that financial planning is a top priority, but use a sub-par proprietary planning software. If you actually want to be a planner, not just in investment sales, you better have good, experienced bankers that can identify those prospects.
advice_to_management: Align banker, branch manager, and advisor compensation.

title: Great place

title: A great challenge

advice_to_management: Consider tangible efforts to at least measure employee wellness.

title: High volume call center
pros:
Benefits
Work from home or hybrid
cons:
• Low Pay for job expected to do
• Micromanagers
• Poor training
• Unrealistic metrics 
• Difficult and stressful calls requiring you to use multiple systems 
• no work or life balance 
• heavy workload 5x the workload on 1 person
• high turnover
advice_to_management: Management needs to advocate for the agents, higher pay for agents, hire more agents and don’t expect the agents to keep doing overtime.

title: Great pay

title: Depends on your team and market assignment

cons:

title: Manager Support Needed
pros: - Commission is good depending on how many deal the FA closes for you
cons: - A supportive team is imperative for your success. If you don’t have a good branch manager or FA, it’ll show in your commission.

title: This place sucks and everyone knows it
pros:
You get a paycheck
Some cool projects
Not as demanding as agencies or consultant firms in some ways
cons:
Dumb product people make decisions but have no idea what design is and just do what the business people tell them
No process or direction yet higher ups expect you to follow them
Five day RTTO even though most of your meetings and teammates are in another state
You're either replacing people with AI or you're the ones being replaced by AI
Toxic culture, minor complaints or feedback can blow up into out of proportion panic for no reason
Constant Micromanagement. Its not enough to do your job or even do your job well. I get that perception matters but here it seems like perception is all that matters.
advice_to_management:
Fire them. Fire yourselves.

I don't know anyone that is happy here. I know that is kind of cliche but honestly when I listened to other people telling me about how much they hate it here, I never felt the same way. Now I do. It's not the worst place I've ever worked at but it is getting there.

title: Good place but same story
pros: Decent pay, coworkers are great, management is good at my specific location although heard bad things at other locations.
cons: Call center so focus is always on output and service levels. Asked multiple times to develop career but always same story, service levels priority.
advice_to_management: Too worried about data and "showing number" for what employees are asking for. No focus on showing values in action but instead focusing on proving that whats being asked for is beneficial.

title: Depends on what side you are on..
pros: Hybrid. work life balance for the week
cons: Multiple issues, Turnover is high, training can leave you behind, cooperate world would let you go for no reason
advice_to_management: Do better

title: Strong learning environment with solid work culture
pros: Supportive team environment, good exposure to modern technologies, structured processes, collaborative culture, and opportunities for professional growth
cons: Workload can be demanding at times, tight deadlines during peak releases, limited flexibility in some projects, and slower decision-making due to multiple approvals.

title: Good place to work, but lacks emphasis on employee benefits
pros: Good work-life balance, decent compensation, interesting work
cons: The firm has transitioned to a fully in-person format, so there is no option for hybrid work.

title: 10/10 terrible place to work
pros: There are no pros to working here
cons: They don't give any raises and constantly expect you to learn new skills and do more and more things for the same job title and pay. My Dr recommended disability accomodation was denied by them because they "recognize it as a disability but don't recognize that I should WFH for it" they are obsessed with being in the office for no reason. They hate WFH because Jamie Dimon threw a fit about zoom. They offer Guild education incentives that go nowhere and keep you in your current role. There is no mobility. The management is terrible. They do not hire anyone that deserves it and don't fire anyone that deserves it. At my previous role we had enforced overtime that if you missed it you could be fired for. They paid everyone the same whether you had a degree or not. There is zero flexibility for anything. And they boast about how they give so much PTO but wont let you work remotely or have the day off if there is an extreme weather event. Multiple times told us we were expected to drive into work during tornado/hail storms when I had the capability to work remotely. They also enforced company wide rto when they didn't have enough space and now plan to expand their site. This would not matter if they just hired people remotely. Covid taught us there are no need for workplaces anymore. Red flags everywhere, do not work here.
advice_to_management: Become flexible. WFH is not the enemy. Get a new CEO.

advice_to_management: stop wasting other people time with interviews when you already made up your mind before accepting applications.

advice_to_management: Time is limited, and lasting value comes from how we treat people and build the organization, not what we accumulate whether your mortgage or pension.

pros: Plenty of smart and capable people working here; generally don't need to work long hours.

No flexibility or hybrid work arrangements, despite distributed teams - most employees spend their entire days on Zoom meetings at their desks. Compensation has not kept up with market rates/inflation, at least for UX roles.

title: Challenging Environment for Agile Professionals Seeking Growth
pros: I worked as a Scrum Master within the SMB Payments group at the Tampa Fountain Square location. While the company itself has strong brand recognition and benefits, my specific experience was marked by significant challenges—primarily due to the team environment and management style. See Cons
cons:
The department I supported had high turnover, which I later learned stemmed from a pattern of micromanagement and a lack of psychological safety within the team. As someone with over a decade of experience in Agile and team coaching, I found it difficult to apply industry best practices or foster true team empowerment under a leadership approach that was controlling, dismissive of collaboration, and unreceptive to coaching principles.

Despite efforts to build trust and enable team autonomy, decisions were often made unilaterally, and feedback was not welcomed. New ideas, especially those aligned with Agile values, were discouraged. This made it nearly impossible to create a healthy team dynamic or sustain meaningful improvement.  If you are an experienced Scrum Master or Agile Coach looking to make an impact, I strongly advise asking thoughtful questions during the interview about leadership style, team culture, and turnover history. This particular department may not be conducive to growth, especially if you value psychological safety, autonomy in your decisions, collaboration, and trust-based leadership.
advice_to_management: Investigate the SMB Payments area in Tampa; in particular, the group that the scrum masters (agility leads) report to, her manager, and the leadership above. Your employees are beat down emotionally and verbally, burnt out, micromanaged, and mistreated. The manager has severe behavioral issues that need to be addressed asap as this is damaging to employees, and costly to the company - high turnover is costly.  Employees are also severely overworked

title: Exciting at first, toxic in the medium to long term
pros:
Above average base pay
Smart people
cons:
Horrible hours
Managers don't reward you - blame you when things go wrong, and don't reward you for extra time you put in
Weak bonuses
No WFH
Absolutely horrible technology - you would be amazed how they can't even get the basics right; spend more time on operational fixes rather than actual work; costs you productivity that you end up getting blamed for
Corporate politics
Taboo to talk about mobility
Cog in a wheel, mundane workdays
Cheap company that doesn't give their employees much, not even a banana, only cheap coffee in breakroom
Coworkers are not your friends, just your coworkers and nothing more; i.e. hard to trust people
advice_to_management:
Wake up it is 2025 - embrace WFH
FIX YOUR TECHNOLOGY!
Stop asking for feedback every year it is the same thing - improve mobility and don't make it taboo to discuss openly
Up your bonuses for people who put in work
800bn+ market cap company and you can't put basic snacks or fruit in the breakroom? Get real

title: Amazing.. Except HR
pros:
Treats contractors like FTEs
Amazing Culture
Recruits the best creative talent
Non-political
Caring, empathetic, driven leadership
cons:
HR 
Demanding and strict hiring guidelines 
Not guaranteed to be converted to FTE or extension
advice_to_management: My team and management were hands down the best I've ever encountered. The advocacy and dedication I received from my managers were unlike anything I had experienced before. I also appreciated the team as a whole because I was finally with people who shared my passion for UX. It was a very comfortable, creative, driven, and encouraging environment. The only complaint I have is that there's a refusal of communication with HR, and I find that they were very incompetent. They made my conversion impossible, in which not only did I suffer greatly, but the Firm did too. Advice to HR: Pay attention. Open lines of communication. Take the time to review the documentation submitted (even if it seems excessive), as requested, and try again. I can only imagine how much talent falls through the cracks due to a lack of communication, organization, and a willingness to gain a deeper understanding of someone's history. For the record, this wasn't an issue with criminal history; I was clean. It was a matter of employment dates and company names affiliated with the brand. DO BETTER.

title: JPMorgan Advisors - A Step Below the Rest of JPMorgan
pros: Good benefits, intelligent employees, collaborative environment, good work-life balance, brand recognition
cons: Lack of internal mobility and exposure to other lines of business, uphill battle against poor platforms/technology, lack of transparency and complex/irrational systems due to merging of multiple companies over the years. At JPM Advisors, it often feels like the line of business is the ugly stepchild of JPMorgan, featuring lower salaries, less prestige, and the general sense that the firm at large has higher priorities.

title: Avoid Personal Avisors unless you want to do gloried client service calls
pros: None. Good benefits but the company and Personal Advisors JPMPA team will screw over every employee including the number 1 top advisor that was instrumental to the departments success and initiatives.
cons:
There is no career advancement. You are just another number. This department will lie to you over and over. This is not real financial advisor work despite them lying to potential new hires in interviews.

The personal advisors platform is nothing more than glorified customer service. Excessive pressure to close business even though it doesn’t make sense for the client. There is no advancement opportunity or growth at JPM. 

“Squeeze every drop out of the lemon”

Management through fear and intimidation 

Managers who yell at the advisors in 1:1 and on the floor in front of peers/management yet the leadership sides with the manager and refuses to transfer the advisor to another team. 

One has to be completely incompetent to get promoted here.

Management will cut advisors off mid sentence, shake their finger and state “oh no we aren’t having any of that.” Even with that leadership refuses to transfer teams. Hostile work environment. Management retaliates and adds aggressive negative feedback in multiple places of performance took that is outright untrue and overly aggressive in nature.
advice_to_management:
Stop lying to employees. Be transparent. Stop micromanaging and treating us like we are client service reps

The site lead, md, and head of personal advisors all need to be removed. The culture is toxic. Some managers need to be fired as well. 

Stop with canned one liners and lying about opportunities that will never come. They literally used one guy, had him build out the annuity team, then threw him to the side and didn’t make him the manager

title: Good experience
pros:
You can systematically learn business attitudes and practical senses.

Colleagues kindly share their professional knowledge and experience, and you can receive a lot of help in your practical growth.

You can get up close and personal with various trends in the global financial market and experience the latest data-driven decision-making processes.

The team atmosphere is collaborative, and you can freely share your opinions with members from different backgrounds.

A systematic training and mentoring system allows for rapid career growth.
cons: The upside for rapid promotion or access to highly diverse projects may be somewhat limited.

title: Best Company in Financial Services
pros:
-They have a great culture and they care about the well-being of their employees
-They have arguably the world's greatest C-Suite leadership
-They are on the cutting edge of technology within the financial services space
-There are lots of opportunities to get promoted and move around within the company
cons:
-They have removed remote and hybrid work schedules at the behest of Jamie Dimon. The full time on-site policy will force them to lose talent over year and is out of touch with current times
-Once you reach VP, promotion above that can be hard as there are not many Executive Director roles and even fewer Managing Director roles. Some folks I know literally stay in VP roles for 10+ years just getting meager 3% yearly raises along the way
advice_to_management: Get rid of the on-site office policy - it simply won't work in the long run. Additionally, create more tiers above VP (Senior VP, Associated Director, etc) so that people have opportunities to get promoted and move up.

title: Great place to grow in data engineering
pros:
Good learning opportunities with access to large-scale data systems.
Supportive team environment with collaborative colleagues.
Exposure to cutting-edge tools and financial technologies.
Strong brand recognition and valuable experience for future roles.
Flexible work culture depending on the project.
cons:
Projects can sometimes be highly demanding with tight deadlines.
Work-life balance can be challenging during peak periods.
Decision-making processes may feel slow due to bureaucracy.
Contract positions may lack the same benefits as full-time roles.
Limited visibility into long-term project strategy.
advice_to_management: Provide more career growth opportunities for contract employees. Streamline internal processes to reduce bureaucracy. Continue investing in modern data technologies to stay competitive.

title: Non Tech Company
pros: Learn Non Transferable Skills, meaning you leave everything on the floor when Quitting the Job and u will as a Software Developer.
cons:
Core Identity: This is not a technology company.

Management Focus: The management culture is strictly top-down. The main priority is achieving metrics and goals passed down from senior leadership, with little emphasis on the process or team autonomy.

Tech Team Structure: There is a rigid separation between roles. Architects design solutions but do not code, which can create a disconnect from the developers who implement the work.

Recruitment Warning: The company's HR department may market it as a "tech company" to attract talent. This branding does not reflect the actual internal culture or priorities.
advice_to_management: Work as a team not an individual contributors. Take feedback from team before designing and handing over to to make it happen as I like.

title: Respected name, cheap company
pros:
-some good coworkers
-respected CEO
cons:
-a toxic branch manager can ruin work for you even if they’re not your direct supervisor. 
-company constantly revamps comp plan that hurts advisors by pushing the goal post or making it harder to get credit for certain accumulation of assets. 
-expects you to work 6 days a week if branch opened on Saturdays for 3-5 years while only making your draw pay and little bonus since grid payouts for bonus is extremely low. 
-have to bend over backwards to get approval to order branded supplies such as a notepad to take client notes with or charger to charge phone that is used to make client calls with. 
-submitted my two week notice and was walked out immediately which is standard procedure. Within the industry, advisors are usually paid the two week notice period. However, was not paid two week notice period.
advice_to_management: Stop being so frugal and cheap.

title: They give us learnings but never dedicated time to complete learnings
pros:
- **Growth Opportunities**: Offers clear career advancement paths and internal mobility. 
- **Employee Resources**: Access to extensive training programs and tools for skill development. 
- **Workplace Diversity**: Promotes an inclusive and diverse work environment. 
- **Reputation**: Working for a globally recognized and respected brand. 
- **Team Support**: Collaborative teams and a strong emphasis on teamwork. 
- **Community Impact**: Opportunities to participate in community outreach programs.
cons:
—Managers expect us to complete training between transactions, leaving little time to focus on learning. We’re expected to skim through videos between customers, which makes it hard to retain information. The quizzes require 80-90% to pass and can be lengthy, yet managers get upset if training isn’t done quickly, despite our branch’s high volume and lack of dedicated training time. This unrealistic approach causes frustration among staff and affects performance. 
—-Stressful at times due to high walk-in traffic, as many customers get upset when bankers are unavailable because they’re assisting clients with scheduled appointments. While some walk-ins expect immediate service, they often haven’t made appointments despite taking time off work/lunch to visit
advice_to_management:
-Focus on problem-solving instead of blame when things go wrong .
-If managers are having a bad day, they should avoid projecting it onto the team. They can practice mindfulness or take a moment to regroup before interacting with the team .
-Inspire, Don’t Intimidate: People respond better to recognition and motivation rather than fear. A rigid, authoritative approach doesn’t resonate anymore.  
-To connect with the new generation, managers should focus on respect, empathy, and collaboration instead of being overly strict. Clear communication and listening to feedback build trust. Empowering employees and solving problems together works better than blame.

title: Competitive benefits, but terrible employee moral
pros: Overall, the benefits at JPMorgan are pretty solid. Above average PTO and sick leave added together with bank holidays. Very competitive or above average salary. The firm is clearly a leader in the financial world and business is doing very well year over year.
cons: C-suite executives can't read the room on company moral which is at rock bottom which is odd for a company that is posting record profits. Bonuses have gone down over the years. WFH is no longer an option for the vast majority of the company. Very old school mentality coming from the top down: in office expectations, micromanaging, using "efficiency" to justify anything negative the company is doing, etc. Not to mention the doing away of diversity programs. In today's political environment, it seems like the CEO is emboldened to do as he pleases as opposed to take into consideration the people actually doing the work.
advice_to_management: Recognize that moral with your employees is in the toilet and do something about it. Simply saying "if they aren't happy, they can leave" isn't helping. Remember who did the heavy lifting to get you those record profits year over year recently...clue: it's not you, but it's the other 300k employees.

title: Great company to work for
pros: Great benefits, competent and friendly coworkers, internal mobility opportunities
cons: Return to office 5 days a week, bureaucracy can really slow down deliverables

title: Politics Politics Politics
pros:
-Almost every piece of software you can imagine is available to you, including AI

-Most Associates and above get 4 weeks paid vacation plus bank holidays

-Industry leader in banking technology

-Challenging work environment teaches you to quickly hone your social engineering skills to get work done
cons:
-Almost no collegial atmosphere due to the vast workload, it's always the next sprint, next release, next initiative. 

-Standing out amongst your fellow employees from a performance perspective seems to be only the beginning of steps to get promoted. If you don't network or directly get seen by senior leaders due to some extraordinary effort or initiative, you won't move up.

-New Return to Office policies are outdated and even archaic for tech workers. If we're on zoom even while in the office, and we work long hours to meet deadlines that make the company money, then what's the point of the additional burden? Hybrid, fine. 5 days in office is just punitive.
advice_to_management:
Push back against ineffective senior leadership who truly have no vision, just a word cloud of buzzwords. AI being one of the biggest.

Hire more senior leaders who are truly technical and know how to bring order to the vast ocean that is JPMC's technology infrastructure

title: REVIEW
pros: Compensation, culture, interesting work, great team environment
cons: I have no negative feedback for this firm.

title: Ladder Climbing
pros: Social environment where you work as a team to help customer needs. Great job to learn about finances. Lots of training that can be accessed at anytime to educate yourself on financial health. Great college programs and benefits. Typical 9-5 job with short Saturday work shifts. Challenging task to complete but can be rewarding to help out customers. Great teller job compared to other banks where you can learn more banker roles and use in your resume. Good career for taking online classes after work. Pay is decent but the part time hours hurts pay checks. Full time hours makes difference when available.
cons: Need to work on sales to climb up ladder even without incentive pay. Easier to apply from the outside with banking experience to get the role you want than to work your way up. This is the culture throughout all SoCal. You’re pretty much a glorified teller as an AB. You do a lot of work as an AB depending on location but it definitely helps to your resume if your looking to apply into a different financial institution. Other than that you must constantly bug your manager and increase your numbers every week to stand out even though you don’t get the incentives a licensed banker earns. Essentially need to be a history of constantly earning numbers to show your worth it to the higher ups. Other than that get used to seeing outside new hires getting the role you want without them fully knowing the system that you already know. Managers are protected even if employees file HR claims. Employees are way more disposable but depending on relationships to managers  you can also be protected but don’t expect it.  Gossiping is huge within this industry as most office environments so be careful on what you share and how you act.
advice_to_management: Needs to be more transparent, quit promising promotions only to already know employees won’t get promoted. They use this tactic to keep employees at the low positions because they  don’t want to promote people who master the lower positions. This wouldn’t be an issue if full time was an option or better raises were available.

title: average company
pros:
office location and environment is perfect.
free snack.
cons:
cafeteria is bad.
engineering culture is just average level.

title: If you are thinking of working here, please read this.
pros:
Please don't skip this if you are considering working here as an engineer.

If you are good at what you do, realistically you can have a really easy job that does not involve working more than a few hours/day. You can use the rest of your time to upskill yourself in other areas, just hopefully for a potential different employer.
cons:
First, I'd advise you to look at the r/JPMorganChase reddit. The general sentiment of that thread reflects all I'd say here in greater detail, but...

- Lack of opportunity to be compensated at a competitive rate to your peers (think ~30% lower on average). For context, when I left for a new job I got about a 50% bump in comp based on skill and experience.
- Lack of opportunity to advance. On multiple occasions people I knew were turned down from promotions because "there are too many people at that level". Nepotism is rampant and extremely deep rooted.
- Toxic culture. Just look at the reddit thread. You aren't an employee, you aren't even a number to them. You are simply a collection of metrics an an attendance count.
- Betting on the wrong things. I get that the commercial real estate market benefits from full RTO, but the fact of the matter is that the company and working environment tends to falter when you take away the one thing that was keeping most of your decent talent in house.
- Overall entrapment: you will spend your time learning internal tools that not only cannot translate to helping you work elsewhere, they will actively contribute to you falling behind your peers in industry. It's an clever but detrimental way to retain personnel if you ask me.

Learn how to actually promote based on merit, and push back against terrible decisions. The people at the top are just people too, and in many cases they aren't as well informed about a given situation as you are, and therefore incapable of making the optimal choice given the circumstances. An org of this size should be able to run itself, but competent people are simply cowed by the arbitrary decisions of other people with fancy titles next to their names.
advice_to_management: Fix the nepotism, fix the culture, and stop letting the c-suite make arbitrary choices for the whole company based on personal preference.

title: No Job Security
pros: As a contractor you get paid well
cons: No benefits. If they hire you full time your pay gets cut, but you don’t have to worry about finding a permanent job. They’ve eliminated any full time positions and replaced them with more temp workers. Seems like you have better job security being a contractor than being an actual employee.
advice_to_management: Probably see who is actually actually walking the walk instead of just talking the talk.

title: It's all about politics

title: Analyst
pros: good culture good people good WLB
cons: return to office is a bit of a pain

title: It is not too bad. It is actually very manageable and comfortable if you know what youa re doing.
pros: There is a lot of flexibity but there is also a lot fo work ethic that you need to put in. I came in from 4 years at uni as I majored in economics and it costed me a heavy ton of emotion and will to get where I am at. It is hard work but it can pay off.
cons: They do pressure you to do a lot of work. It is pretty insane to work throughout the times. They ask you sometimes to stay a little overtime but in the end it will help you with more skills.
advice_to_management: Please do not force upon the interns instead teach them the value of hard work. The value of putting in long hours and the pay and respect you can earn from it.

title: Private Bank Associate
pros: good pay, culture, room to grow
cons: pressure to bring in business

title: If you like your family, don't work here
pros: The people you work with are generally great, which is good because work/life balance is non-existent.
cons:
Salary is considerably less that other banks. (You'll be told it's because you get JPMorgan on your resume.)
Hours are insane. Don't expect to take a vacation without bringing work with you.
Hybrid work is no longer an option. There's been high turnover since people had to go back into the office, even hybrid, because people don't want to put in the time IN the office.
advice_to_management: Stop listening to Jamie, and let roles that can work remotely do it. Use benchmarks, etc., to prove employees are working. I've watched employees sleep, watch movies, and play video games at their desks, so being in the office has no actual benefit, regardless of what Jamie says.

title: Hard work, Experience is regional
pros: Great pay, great Benefits. Good earning potential when you leave
cons: Toxic work culture, Long hours. No pay transparency. Toxic management

title: Summer Analyst in Real Estate Investment Banking
pros: One of the most comprehensive, high impact training programs through Financial Edge, line of business training, and sub group training. We spent 1.5 weeks (out of 9) focused on modeling, technicals, and coverage group specifics with incredibly investment from Financial Edge teachers and firm employees.
cons: The hours are demanding and recruiters may be stiff when it comes to flexibility, accommodations, etc. Classic don't get in the way vibe, and check yourself.
advice_to_management: Focus recruitment on supporting junior staff, instead of sourcing and training them.

title: Easy job

title: Extra hours available

advice_to_management: Train them as properly as expected to be able to assist agents. A lot of  times not available except to sign monthly goals.

title: Great culture, supportive environment
pros: The GFBM program is a great way to transition into the JPMC as there is a lot of support from both the program managers and your team. Teams that have roles for GFBM analysts expect to do some mentoring and both teams I was on were very good about offering support throughout my time on their teams.
cons: Mild con is that a role in the company isn't 100% guaranteed when your two year GFBM program is complete, but there is a lot of coaching to help you land a permanent role and the company has made a point of factoring the GFBM program into their long term hiring strategy. So if you do well in the two year program , the lack of guarantee shouldn't be too much of a problem as you should be able to land something.
